Situation1: They have argued repeatedly this week about finances.
Expectation2: Repair or replace damaged wooden structures or components
Situation2: A homeowner reports a damaged wooden deck, and the carpenter needs to repair or replace it to restore functionality
Story: I stared at my phone, rereading the last message from my boyfriend. We’d argued again last night—this time about money, about how I spend too much, how he worries about our future. I know he expects me to reach out, to smooth things over, to be the one who resolves our conflicts. But as I sat in my truck outside a client’s house, my mind was already shifting to the deck repair I’d been called for. The homeowner was waiting, expecting me to assess the damage and get started right away. I could see the splintered boards from the driveway, and I knew it would take hours to fix. My phone buzzed again. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in—my boyfriend’s need for reassurance, the homeowner’s need for a safe, sturdy deck. I gripped the steering wheel, torn between the urge to call him and the responsibility to get to work. My heart pounded as I tried to figure out which role needed me more right now.
